verses.kjv: And Paul, earnestly beholding the council, said, Men and brethren, I have lived in all good conscience before God until this day.
verses.ct: Paul looked directly at the council and said, "Brothers, I have lived my life with a completely clear conscience before God up to this very day."

verses.kjv: And the high priest Ananias commanded them that stood by him to smite him on the mouth.
verses.ct: The high priest Ananias ordered those standing near Paul to strike him on the mouth.

verses.kjv: Then said Paul unto him, God shall smite thee, thou whited wall: for sittest thou to judge me after the law, and commandest me to be smitten contrary to the law?
verses.ct: Paul said to him, "God is going to strike you, you whitewashed wall! You sit there to judge me according to the law, and yet you order me to be hit in violation of that same law?"

verses.kjv: And they that stood by said, Revilest thou God’s high priest?
verses.ct: Those standing nearby said, "How dare you insult God's high priest!"

verses.kjv: Then said Paul, I wist not, brethren, that he was the high priest: for it is written, Thou shalt not speak evil of the ruler of thy people.
verses.ct: Paul replied, "I didn't realize he was the high priest, brothers. The Scripture does say, 'You must not speak against the ruler of your people.'"

verses.kjv: But when Paul perceived that the one part were Sadducees, and the other Pharisees, he cried out in the council, Men and brethren, I am a Pharisee, the son of a Pharisee: of the hope and resurrection of the dead I am called in question.
verses.ct: When Paul noticed that part of the council were Sadducees and the others were Pharisees, he called out to them, "Brothers, I am a Pharisee and the son of a Pharisee. I am on trial because of my hope in the resurrection of the dead!"

verses.kjv: And when he had so said, there arose a dissension between the Pharisees and the Sadducees: and the multitude was divided.
verses.ct: As soon as he said this, a fierce argument broke out between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly split into 2 opposing sides.

verses.kjv: For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, neither angel, nor spirit: but the Pharisees confess both.
verses.ct: The Sadducees claim there is no resurrection, and that neither angels nor spirits exist, but the Pharisees affirm all of these.

verses.kjv: And there arose a great cry: and the scribes that were of the Pharisees’ part arose, and strove, saying, We find no evil in this man: but if a spirit or an angel hath spoken to him, let us not fight against God.
verses.ct: A huge uproar erupted. Some of the legal experts who belonged to the Pharisee party stood up and argued forcefully, "We don't find anything wrong with this man. What if a spirit or an angel actually spoke to him? We shouldn't be fighting against God."

verses.kjv: And when there arose a great dissension, the chief captain, fearing lest Paul should have been pulled in pieces of them, commanded the soldiers to go down, and to take him by force from among them, and to bring him into the castle.
verses.ct: The dispute became so violent that the commanding officer was afraid Paul would be torn apart by them. He ordered soldiers to go down, pull Paul out of the crowd by force, and bring him back to the barracks.

verses.kjv: And the night following the Lord stood by him, and said, Be of good cheer, Paul: for as thou hast testified of me in Jerusalem, so must thou bear witness also at Rome.
verses.ct: That night the Lord stood near Paul and said, "Take courage, Paul! Just as you have testified about me in Jerusalem, you must also testify in Rome."

verses.kjv: And when it was day, certain of the Jews banded together, and bound themselves under a curse, saying that they would neither eat nor drink till they had killed Paul.
verses.ct: When morning came, a group of Jews formed a conspiracy and made a solemn oath that they would not eat or drink until they had killed Paul.

verses.kjv: And they were more than forty which had made this conspiracy.
verses.ct: More than 40 men were involved in this plot.

verses.kjv: And they came to the chief priests and elders, and said, We have bound ourselves under a great curse, that we will eat nothing until we have slain Paul.
verses.ct: They went to the chief priests and elders and said, "We have made a binding oath not to eat anything until we have killed Paul."

verses.kjv: Now therefore ye with the council signify to the chief captain that he bring him down unto you to morrow, as though ye would enquire something more perfectly concerning him: and we, or ever he come near, are ready to kill him.
verses.ct: "So here's what we need you to do: you and the council should send a request to the commanding officer to bring Paul down to you tomorrow, pretending that you want to examine his case more thoroughly. We'll be ready to kill him before he even gets there."

verses.kjv: And when Paul’s sister’s son heard of their lying in wait, he went and entered into the castle, and told Paul.
verses.ct: But Paul's nephew — his sister's son — heard about the ambush. He went to the barracks and told Paul about it.

verses.kjv: Then Paul called one of the centurions unto him, and said, Bring this young man unto the chief captain: for he hath a certain thing to tell him.
verses.ct: Paul called one of the centurions over and said, "Take this young man to the commanding officer. He has important information for him."

verses.kjv: So he took him, and brought him to the chief captain, and said, Paul the prisoner called me unto him, and prayed me to bring this young man unto thee, who hath something to say unto thee.
verses.ct: So the centurion brought him to the commanding officer and said, "The prisoner Paul called me over and asked me to bring this young man to you. He has something to tell you."

verses.kjv: Then the chief captain took him by the hand, and went with him aside privately, and asked him, What is that thou hast to tell me?
verses.ct: The commanding officer took the young man by the hand, led him to a private spot, and asked, "What do you need to tell me?"

verses.kjv: And he said, The Jews have agreed to desire thee that thou wouldest bring down Paul to morrow into the council, as though they would enquire somewhat of him more perfectly.
verses.ct: He said, "The Jewish leaders have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down to the council tomorrow, claiming they want to question him more thoroughly."

verses.kjv: But do not thou yield unto them: for there lie in wait for him of them more than forty men, which have bound themselves with an oath, that they will neither eat nor drink till they have killed him: and now are they ready, looking for a promise from thee.
verses.ct: "But don't agree to it! More than 40 of them are hiding along the route, waiting to ambush him. They've sworn an oath not to eat or drink until they've killed him. They're ready right now, just waiting for your approval."

verses.kjv: So the chief captain then let the young man depart, and charged him, See thou tell no man that thou hast shewed these things to me.
verses.ct: The commanding officer dismissed the young man with a warning: "Don't tell anyone that you reported this to me."

verses.kjv: And he called unto him two centurions, saying, Make ready two hundred soldiers to go to Caesarea, and horsemen threescore and ten, and spearmen two hundred, at the third hour of the night;
verses.ct: Then he summoned 2 centurions and said, "Get 200 soldiers ready to march to Caesarea, along with 70 horsemen and 200 spearmen. Be ready to leave at 9 tonight."

verses.kjv: And provide them beasts, that they may set Paul on, and bring him safe unto Felix the governor.
verses.ct: "Also, provide horses for Paul to ride, and make sure he arrives safely to Governor Felix."

verses.kjv: And he wrote a letter after this manner:
verses.ct: He also wrote a letter that went something like this:

verses.kjv: Claudius Lysias unto the most excellent governor Felix sendeth greeting.
verses.ct: "Claudius Lysias, to His Excellency Governor Felix — greetings."

verses.kjv: This man was taken of the Jews, and should have been killed of them: then came I with an army, and rescued him, having understood that he was a Roman.
verses.ct: "This man had been seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them. I intervened with my troops and rescued him when I learned that he is a Roman citizen."

verses.kjv: And when I would have known the cause wherefore they accused him, I brought him forth into their council:
verses.ct: "Wanting to understand what they were accusing him of, I brought him before their council."

verses.kjv: Whom I perceived to be accused of questions of their law, but to have nothing laid to his charge worthy of death or of bonds.
verses.ct: "I found that their charges involved disputes about their own religious law, but there was nothing against him that deserved death or imprisonment."

verses.kjv: And when it was told me how that the Jews laid wait for the man, I sent straightway to thee, and gave commandment to his accusers also to say before thee what they had against him. Farewell.
verses.ct: "When I was informed of a plot against the man, I immediately sent him to you. I have also instructed his accusers to present their case against him before you."

verses.kjv: Then the soldiers, as it was commanded them, took Paul, and brought him by night to Antipatris.
verses.ct: So the soldiers carried out their orders. They took Paul during the night and brought him as far as Antipatris.

verses.kjv: On the morrow they left the horsemen to go with him, and returned to the castle:
verses.ct: The next day, the foot soldiers returned to the barracks while the horsemen continued on with Paul.

verses.kjv: Who, when they came to Caesarea, and delivered the epistle to the governor, presented Paul also before him.
verses.ct: When they arrived in Caesarea, they delivered the letter to the governor and brought Paul before him.

verses.kjv: And when the governor had read the letter, he asked of what province he was. And when he understood that he was of Cilicia;
verses.ct: After reading the letter, the governor asked what province Paul was from. When he learned that Paul was from Cilicia,

verses.kjv: I will hear thee, said he, when thine accusers are also come. And he commanded him to be kept in Herod’s judgment hall.
verses.ct: he said, "I will give you a full hearing when your accusers arrive as well." Then he ordered Paul to be held under guard in Herod's palace.
